description: Erection of single storey side and rear extension, two storey rear extension, loft conversion with 2no. dormer windows and addition of Juliet balcony to front elevation.
decision_conditions: The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason: As required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

The facing materials to be used in the construction of the building shall be those specified on the application form and approved drawings or such other materials as have been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before the development is commenced and shall thereafter be retained as such.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or reenacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the flank walls of the extension hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority.Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments, including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of single-storey rear/side extension with associated changes to fenestrationConsultationForty Seven neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.DesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The principle properties to be considered with regard to neighbouring amenity are No. 13 & No. 17 Portman Road.  Due to the separation between No. 15 & No. 17 the proposed rear and side infill extension would comply with BRE guidance in relation to loss of daylight/sunlight. With regard to No. 13 Portland Road which adjoins No. 15, the existing situation at the rear of the properties in relation to the existing outriggers would not lead to further loss of light or an overbearing appearance. It is therefore considered overall, that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details for Condition 12 (Landscaping Scheme) of planning permission 20/00598/FUL have been assessed by relevant consultants and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details.

The site comprises a terraced dwelling. 17 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 2 objections have been received from 1 neighbouring property relating to:- Access or traffic problems- Car park issues- Fumes- Noise- Excessive height or bulk of buildings- Inadequate landscaping/means of enclosure- Inappropriate design/layout- Loss of light/Sunlight- Privacy- Support- Unacceptable or incompatible useOfficers note there would be no proposed change to car parking provision on site, as such the current provision is considered acceptable. Comments with regards to disturbance during are noted, however, excessive disturbance would be controlled by other legislative, the development proposed would not be unusual in a built up area and no evidence has been provided that would demonstrate that the construction of the proposal would cause harm to the occupants of neighbouring properties.Further, the proposed use would continue as a residential dwelling and as such, officers consider that there would be no material increase in fumes or noise as a result of the proposed development. The remaining concerns raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey side/rear extension would adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, and as such officers consider it to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given that both neighbouring properties benefit from existing rear extensions at ground level, officers consider that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).
